text: hi everyone anthony Fantan oh here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Otis brown
the third record the thought of you
modern rhythm powerhouse Otis brown the
third a drummer who has been been the
rhythmic backing for many a jazz artist
including the popular and Grammy
award-winning Esperanza Spalding and
avant-gardist like Oliver Lake
this is his full-length debut LP which
caught my ear
mainly because Otis seems to have the
same affinity as me for 50s 60s 70s era
quartet quintet Trio style jazz
recordings and particularly for me it is
the drum sound of these records that I
find to be so attractive so clear so
crisp so Bumi's so close so intimate
it's like I'm actually inside the drum
set this is a sound this is a feeling
that Brown and his co-producer Derek
Hodge we're very careful to recreate it
is incredibly fitting that this album is
coming out in partnership with Blue Note
Records one of the most notorious and
important jazz labels during this era of
jazz now being that Brown is a drummer
and this is his album rhythm does play
an incredibly pivotal role in these
songs rarely do I come across a drummer
that I find there playing to be
expressive and and this is definitely
one of those instances usually an
adjective reserved for people who are
playing more tonal instrumentation but
there's an incredible amount of feeling
in the way that Brown brings this
pitter-patter percussion to the surprise
cover of Shania Twain's you're still the
one Otis is playing on this track is
really busy but incredibly gentle there
are also a few gospel renditions on this
record my favorite being the one on the
very end of this LP I am your song and
it is amazing how Brown just enhances
the rising horns and Nicky Ross's vocals
is just the song grows and expands and
gets louder of course there are a load
of other musicians on this LP out
died of braun himself for one Robert
Glasper is on piano key on Harold on
trumpet Ben Williams on bass John Ellis
on sax Shedrick Mitchell on organ and
near Felder on guitar the song choices
on this LP whether they be original or
covers seem to revolve around themes of
family and faith and love specifically
love for his wife who there is a few
tributes to on this album my favorite
being the beautiful wonderful
instrumentation on the track the two
become one weaved into these gorgeous
expressive just really tear-jerking
horns there is an audio clip of what
seems to be somebody officiating a
marriage the bass intro to the track is
great Robert Glasper piano flourishes
throughout the track are wonderful and
the horn harmonies are just killer
there's just a lot of mature familial
love throughout this LP also on the
three parts of the title track of this
album the thought of you which features
vocals from neo-soul singer Bilal which
has a very jumpy nimble jagged vocal
melody on the track that just sticks
with me the thought of you please mine
so bad now this track like I said is
separated into three different songs
which are spread throughout the track
listing of the album the first part of
these three songs being centered around
bob style jam loaded with fiery trumpet
solos and even though brown's band is
just water tight throughout this song I
guess I was a little underwhelmed by
this track because it wasn't really an
incredibly refreshing sound for this
style of jazz and another thing that I
don't really gravitate toward with this
track is the fact that it is split up in
such a way where like on part two it
seems like we're entering the song mid
jam which in fact we may be because the
end of the first part seems sort of
finished with the song just coming to a
very slow halt as if in the middle of
the track somebody just turned off the
turntable
maybe this second part would have been
more enthralling had it been attached to
the first in some way and then for the
final section of this song I do dig it a
little bit because it does bring a
pretty significant change to the table I
think Robert Glasper soloing on this
track is great really melodic and
complex but not too hurried or flashy
tracks I'm getting a lot of enjoyment
out of are like the opener the way truth
and life which has this really dizzying
strange and angular theme melody that is
really difficult to wrap my head around
but still is very catchy there's some
really intense sax soloing on the song
punctuated by piano flourishes from
Glasper Brown is playing harder as the
band is playing harder almost as if he's
egging them on and I love the song
stages of thought which has this really
ominous looming lumbering lead melody to
it that I think is one of the darkest on
the entire record it's a really focused
fearsome Jam the bass and drum groove on
this track is just nasty and then all of
a sudden toward the back end of this
track Brown breaks into what kind of
feels like a hip-hop being Glasper
complements it with these weird
ascending descending sour piano notes
and together this makes for something
that sounds like it could come from a
wu-tang record then there is the 8
minute gospel medley toward the back end
of this track with vocals from Nicki
Ross throughout much of these passages
and this track is basically like your
local Baptist Church's music program on
steroids brown and company are are
really not writing or delivering concise
renditions of these songs in the same
way that they did the Shania Twain track
they are really just riffing on these
tracks but still managing to muster some
some really wonderful building intensity
especially on tracks like we exalt thee
which seems to build higher and higher
and higher with every crushing blow of
vocals drums and horns overall it's not
a bad record in fact it is a very good
and varied jazz record
there are some tracks I didn't really
care for as much as others and I think
overall maybe the album is a tad sort of
rocky in terms of its flow there are
some interludes on this track as well
which I don't really care for all that
much and there are spots like the broken
up in section title track that I don't
really see playing that well in between
key tracks of this LP but still if
you're looking for a modern jazz record
with some great composition some great
improvisation and a fantastic vintage
style recording then I implore to you to
give this album a listen I'm feeling a
decent too strong seven on this thing
transition if you've given this record
to listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantana
Otis brown the third thought of you
subscribe please
forever
